item.title: Wsl for OpenSUSE
item.author: me@example.com (author)
item.description:
installation

Âú®Windows terminal‰∏≠ËæìÂÖ•

 wsl --list -o

Êü•ÁúãÂèØÂÆâË£ÖÁöÑÂàÜÂèëÂàóË°®Ôºö

NAME FRIENDLY NAME
Ubuntu Ubuntu
Debian Debian GNU/Linux
kali-linux Kali Linux Rolling
Ubuntu-18.04 Ubuntu 18.04 LTS
Ubuntu-20.04 Ubuntu 20.04 LTS
Ubuntu-22.04 Ubuntu 22.04 LTS
OracleLinux_7_9 Oracle Linux 7.9
OracleLinux_8_7 Oracle Linux 8.7
OracleLinux_9_1 Oracle Linux 9.1
openSUSE-Leap-15.5 openSUSE Leap 15.5
SUSE-Linux-Enterprise-Server-15-SP4 SUSE Linux Enterprise Server 15 SP4
SUSE-Linux-Enterprise-15-SP5 SUSE Linux Enterprise 15 SP5
openSUSE-Tumbleweed openSUSE Tumbleweed

‰ΩøÁî® wsl.exe --install <Distro> ÂÆâË£Ö„ÄÇ

 wsl --install openSUSE-Leap-15.5

ÊåâÁÖßÊåáÁ§∫ÂàõÂª∫Áî®Êà∑ÂêçÂØÜÁ†ÅÂÆâË£ÖÂç≥ÂèØ„ÄÇ

Êü•ÁúãÁâàÊú¨‰ø°ÊÅØcat /etc/os-release

NAME="openSUSE Leap"
VERSION="15.5"
ID="opensuse-leap"
ID_LIKE="suse opensuse"
VERSION_ID="15.5"
PRETTY_NAME="openSUSE Leap 15.5"
ANSI_COLOR="0;32"
CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:opensuse:leap:15.5"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.opensuse.org"
HOME_URL="https://www.opensuse.org/"
DOCUMENTATION_URL="https://en.opensuse.org/Portal:Leap"
LOGO="distributor-logo-Leap"

mirror repository openSUSE Ê∫ê‰ΩøÁî®Â∏ÆÂä© ‚Äî USTC Mirror Help ÊñáÊ°£

Á°ÆËÆ§ÂΩìÂâçÈÖçÁΩÆÁöÑËΩØ‰ª∂Ê∫êÔºõ

sudo zypper lr -d

Á¶ÅÁî®ÂéüÊúâËΩØ‰ª∂Ê∫êÔºõ

sudo zypper mr -da

Ê∑ªÂä†ÁßëÂ§ßÈïúÂÉèÊ∫êÔºå‰ª• openSUSE Leap ‰∏∫‰æãÔºö

sudo zypper ar -fcg 'https://mirrors.ustc.edu.cn/opensuse/distribution/leap/$releasever/repo/oss' USTC:OSS
sudo zypper ar -fcg 'https://mirrors.ustc.edu.cn/opensuse/distribution/leap/$releasever/repo/non-oss' USTC:NON-OSS
sudo zypper ar -fcg 'https://mirrors.ustc.edu.cn/opensuse/update/leap/$releasever/oss' USTC:UPDATE-OSS
sudo zypper ar -fcg 'https://mirrors.ustc.edu.cn/opensuse/update/leap/$releasever/non-oss' USTC:UPDATE-NON-OSS

ÂØπ‰∫é 15.3 ÊàñÊõ¥È´òÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑ openSUSE LeapÔºåËøòÈúÄÊ∑ªÂä† SLE Êõ¥Êñ∞Ê∫êÂíå Backports Êõ¥Êñ∞Ê∫êÔºö

sudo zypper ar -fcg 'https://mirrors.ustc.edu.cn/opensuse/update/leap/$releasever/sle' USTC:UPDATE-SLE
sudo zypper ar -fcg 'https://mirrors.ustc.edu.cn/opensuse/update/leap/$releasever/backports' USTC:UPDATE-BACKPORTS

# refresh repository
sudo zypper refresh
# list packages that can be updated
zypper lu

surf the internet

# fonts used in firefox
sudo zypper in wqy-microhei-fonts
# install firefox
sudo zypper install MozillaFirefox

programming for fun Rust Programming Language (rust-lang.org)

# If you‚Äôre a Windows Subsystem for Linux user run the following in your terminal, 
# then follow the on-screen instructions to install Rust.
curl --proto '=https' --tlsv1.2 -sSf https://sh.rustup.rs | sh
# follow the instruction to finish the installation.
# to configure your current shell, run:
source "$HOME/.cargo/env"
# install rust-analyzer
rustup component add rust-analyzer
# install cross-compile tools
rustup target add x86_64-pc-windows-gnu
rustup toolchain install stable-x86_64-pc-windows-gnu
sudo zypper in mingw64-cross-gcc-c++
# cargo build --release --target x86_64-pc-windows-gnu

neovim and LazyVim/LazyVim: Neovim config for the lazy (github.com)

# network interface through clash for windows
# append the following three lines to .bashrc
export http_proxy=172.20.224.1:65353
export https_proxy=172.20.224.1:65353
export socks_proxy=172.20.224.1:65353

# to apply those changes instantly, run:
source .bashrc

# download nvim.appimage
wget https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/download/nightly/nvim.appimage
# use `chmod u+x nvim.appimage && ./nvim.appimage` and get a failure with message:
# AppImages require FUSE to run.
# You might still be able to extract the contents of this AppImage
# if you run it with the --appimage-extract option.
# See https://github.com/AppImage/AppImageKit/wiki/FUSE
# for more information
./nvim.appimage --appimage-extract
# move squashfs-root directory to root
sudo mv squashfs-root/ /
# create a symbolic link 
sudo ln -s /squashfs-root/AppRun /usr/bin/nvim

# install lazy-vim https://github.com/LazyVim/LazyVim
# https://www.lazyvim.org/installation

# install git
sudo zypper install git-core

# install gcc
sudo zypper install gcc
sudo zypper in gcc-c++

# Clone the starter
git clone https://github.com/LazyVim/starter ~/.config/nvim

# Remove the .git folder, so you can add it to your own repo later
rm -rf ~/.config/nvim/.git

add .config/nvim/init.lua

require("lspconfig").rust_analyzer.setup({})

custom commands in .bashrc

# custom
export rust_prj=/mnt/g/mao/Documents/Github/rust_prj
export myWebSite=/mnt/g/mao/Documents/Github/myWebSite/
export prj_euler=/mnt/g/mao/Documents/Github/ProjectEuler/

vim

  • open a url: place the cursor on the url and type gx.
  • copy: y
  • paste: p
  • delete: d

rustlings

curl -L sh.rustlings.cool | bash

trouble or bugs happensed to me

Input/output error https://github.com/microsoft/WSL/issues/4377

That error occurs if the hidden wslhost.exe process is died/killed. Just use wsl.exe --shutdown and restart it.

item.title: ‰∏úÂçóÂ§ßÂ≠¶Êï∞Â≠¶ÂçöÂ£´Â≠¶‰ΩçÊàêÊûúËÄÉÊ†∏Ê†áÂáÜ
item.author: me@example.com (author)
item.description:
ÂçöÂ£´Â≠¶‰ΩçÊàêÊûúËÄÉÊ†∏Ê†áÂáÜÊ±áÊÄª

ÂçöÂ£´Â≠¶‰ΩçÊàêÊûúËÄÉÊ†∏Ê†áÂáÜÊ±áÊÄªÔºåËØ∑Êü•ÁúãÔºöÁ†îÁ©∂ÁîüÈô¢-Â≠¶‰ΩçÊïôËÇ≤-Â≠¶‰ΩçÊéà‰∫à-ËßÑÁ´†Âà∂Â∫¶ (seu.edu.cn)„ÄÇËØ¶ËßÅ„Ää‰∏úÂçóÂ§ßÂ≠¶ÂçöÂ£´Á†îÁ©∂ÁîüÁî≥ËØ∑ÂçöÂ£´Â≠¶‰Ωç ÁöÑÊàêÊûúËÄÉÊ†∏Ê†áÂáÜÔºà2018 ÁâàÔºâ„Äã„ÄÇ

ÁßëÁ†îÊàêÊûúÁΩ≤Âêç

ÂçöÂ£´Â≠¶‰ΩçÁî≥ËØ∑ËÄÖÁöÑÂ≠¶ÊúØËÆ∫ÊñáÂøÖÈ°ª‰ª•‰∏úÂçóÂ§ßÂ≠¶‰∏∫Á¨¨‰∏ÄÁΩ≤ÂêçÂçï‰ΩçÔºå Âç≥ËÆ∫ÊñáÁ¨¨‰∏Ä‰ΩúËÄÖÂíåÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÈÄöËÆØ‰ΩúËÄÖÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÁΩ≤ÂêçÂçï‰ΩçÂøÖÈ°ªÂùá‰∏∫‚Äú‰∏úÂçóÂ§ß Â≠¶‚ÄùÊàñ‚Äú‰∏úÂçóÂ§ßÂ≠¶ÊüêÊú∫ÊûÑ‚Äù„ÄÇÈô§ÁâπÂà´Ê≥®ÊòéÂ§ñÔºåÂ≠¶‰ΩçÁî≥ËØ∑ËÄÖÂøÖÈ°ªÊòØÂ≠¶ÊúØ ËÆ∫ÊñáÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏Ä‰ΩúËÄÖ„ÄÇ

ÊúüÂàäËÆ§ÂÆöÊ†áÂáÜ

item.title: Excerpts of Academic English
item.author: me@example.com (author)
item.description:
Excerpts

Abstract

  • The results of the paper partially extend previous works of Hu and Tao, and of Tao and Winkler.

Introduction

  • A positive constant determined by $l$ besides $\tau$ (possibly changing from line to line) is henceforth denoted by $C_l$.

  • Here and henceforth, $T_{max}$ denotes the maximal time of the existence of the solution, and $|\cdot|_p$ is the standard $L_p$ norm

  • We do not wish to give further physical motivations for the present analysis and address the reader to Refs. [CLMP, Ki] and especially [ES, MP] for a more detailed presentation of the matter and additional references.

  • Before to do this let us recall that a domain A is strictly star-shaped if (modulo translations of the origin) there exists Œ± > 0, such that $$ x \cdot v(x) \geqq \alpha>0 \quad \text { when } \quad x \in \partial \Lambda $$ where $v(x)$ is the outer normal to $\Lambda$ in $x$.

  • under a suitable smallness condition on the initial data, we show that solutions exist globally and converge exponentially to a constant.

  • An external chemoattractant source is provided in the form of a Dirac distribution scaled by some positive constant

  • We‚Äôll refer to the environments generically as ‚Äúalign‚Äù and will distinguish between them explicitly only when necessary.

  • The term “BIOS” in this user guide refers to “UEFI BIOS” unless otherwise specified.

  • The volume-filling approach provides an intuitive way into how density-dependent chemotactic mod- els may be realistically derived.

  • We have so far ignored the potential role of cell kinetics. This may be a reasonable modelling assumption for certain systems, for example during the aggregation stages of Dictyostelium discoideum when cell proliferation has halted, or if the time-scale of movement is significantly faster than that of cell growth.

  • Along the paper we use the following notation $$ ‚ü®f‚ü© := \frac1{\Omega}\int_\Omega f $$ for the average value of function $f ‚àà L^1(‚Ñ¶)$.

  • Throughout the paper we denote generic constants by C which may vary line by line according to the context.

  • $C$ always denotes a generic positive constant.

  • Throughout this paper, the domain $\Omega$ and the non-trivial initial function $u_0$ are only confined to the following case:

    • $\Omega$ is the open ball of radius $L$ with center at the origin in $R^N$.

    • $u_o$ is radially symmetric when $N \geq 2$.

  • Here we note that $W$ itself is bounded above for all times by the constant $nMR^n$, whereas the original function $u$ blows up if and only if the derivative $W_s(s, t) ‚â° \frac1nu(r, t)$ does. Accordingly, we are interested in gradient blow-up in the problem (3.6), and as we shall see below, such behaviour occurs if $u_0$ is such that its initial mass is sufficiently strongly concentrated near $r = 0$.

  • We adopt the usual convention that two functions are considered equal if they agree except on a set of $\mu$-measure zero. Then we denote by $L_p(U, d\mu)$ (or simply $L_p(d\mu)$, $L_p(U)$ or even $L_p$) the Lebesgue-space of (all equivalence classes of) scalar-valued $\mu$-measurable functions $f$ on $U$, such that $$ |f|{L_p} = (\int_u|f(x)|^pd\mu)^{1/p} $$ is finite. Here we have $1\leqslant p<\infty$. In the limiting case, $p=\infty$, $L_p$ consists of all $\mu$-measurable and bounded functions. Then we write $$ |f|{L_\infty}=\sup_U|f(x)|. $$

  • Here we shall reproduce the elementary proof which was given by Thorin.

  • The theory of linear and quasilinear parabolic evolution equations, outlined so far, uses crucially the smoothing property of parabolic equations. This regularizing effect is the ultimate reason for the validity of global existence theorems based on a priori estimates in ‘weak’ norms, that is, norms involving little regularity of the solutions only. —- Amann

  • First, the theory of monotone operators can sometimes be applied. However, it requires rather stringent conditions for the operators and nonlinearties and applies to a small class of problems only, leaving aside most systems of interest.

  • This lack of regularity renders it rather difficult - if not impossible - to develop a dynamical systems theory and to use techniques from nonlinear analysis to establish qualitative properties of the solution set.

  • It tells us, roughly speaking, that the quasilinear Cauchy problem (43) has the same behavior - as far as local existence and continuous dependence of the solutions on the data are concerned - as an ordinary differential equation: $y’ = P(t, y)$ in the finite-dimensional setting. In addition, since our solutions are weak $W^1_2$-solutions as well, they coincide on the common interval of existence with weak $W^1_2$-solutions obtained by any other method, provided there is a uniqueness theorem for weak $W^1_2$-solutions.

  • In the following, we adopt the usual convention not to distinguish (in notation) between a measurable function and its equivalence class modulo functions vanishing almost everywhere.

  • We remark that $\limsup$ in (1.1) for solutions of (P) can be replaced with $\lim$ (see [23,27]).

  • In two dimensions, to the best of our knowledge, the first result on finite-time blowup was shown in [19] for radial solutions of (JL) on a disk.

  • Under a restricted condition on $\partial\Omega$, we show the finite-time blowup of nonradial solutions, provided that $\int_\Omega u_0 d x > 4\pi$ and $\int_\Omega u_0 |x-q|^2dx$ is sufficiently small.

  • In our construction, to have solutions global in time, it is sufficient to obtain an a priori estimate on the $L^2(\Omega)$ norm of $(u, v)$ locally uniform in time. We will show such an estimate in certain cases in the next section, but here we would like to point out that in the case of $\Omega\subset R^3$, it suffices to have such an estimate only in $L^p, p > 3/2$. This follows from Amann‚Äôs theory of parabolic systems with nonlinear boundary conditions (a personal communication).

  • Denoting by $f(t, x, v)$ the cell number density, at time $t$, position $x \in R^d$ moving with a velocity $v \in V$, the governing evolution equation of this process is described by a kinetic equation reading as:

In the sequel we will be performing some formal calculations leading to differential inequalities, but we will understand them in the proper integral formulation like the energy relations above.

  • If (37) is satisfied, then from the compactness of imbeddings $H^1(\Omega) \subset \subset L^q(\Omega), 3<q<6$, $H^1(\Omega) \subset \subset L^r(\partial \Omega), 2<r<4$, we conclude that there exist functions $w, z \in L^q(\Omega) \cap L^r(\partial \Omega)$ such that $w=\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} u^{1 / 2}\left(t_k\right), z=\lim _{k \rightarrow \infty} v^{1 / 2}\left(t_k\right)$ in the above space along a subsequence of $t_k \mathrm{~s}$.

Similarity

  • At this stage, we can reproduce the argument of [20].
  • The proof is done along a similar line, but estimates near the boundary are more crucial.
  • Now we take the reflection process of [20].

Brevity

  • We drop the suffix $n$ for simplicity of writing.
  • for the sake of simplicity
  • Here and later on, C will denote a constant independent of blabla and A.
  • Without any danger of confusion we shall write $u = u(r, t)$ for $r = |x|$ throughout.
  • The constant $C$ depends also on the space dimension $n$ but here and in the following we will suppress any dependence on $n$.

Obviousness

  • The following lemma is elementary, but we provide with the proof for completeness.

Conclusion

Remark

  • Having in mind the remarks in the Introduction on the nonexistence of global solutions emanating from large initial data for this problem, we should note that any attempt to prove the global existence of solutions in the electrolytic case needs a more subtle analysis of the terms on the right-hand sides of (9) and (10).
  • the integral $\int_\Omega u\nabla v\cdot\nabla v$ (even after certain integration by parts) in the general case cannot be estimated crudely for $n = 3$ using the Sobolev-Gagliardo-Nirenberg inequalities.
  • The reason is that the, so-called, net smoothness of the only terms $l<u, u>l_2^2$, $|\nabla<u, u>|_2^2$ that could be used to compensate the above integral is strictly less than its net smoothness.
  • In particular, theorem 10.1 in Chapter III of [13] gives the H√∂lder continuity: $u, v \in C^{\alpha, \alpha / 2}(\Omega \times(0, T))$ with some $\alpha \in(0,1)$, and the H√∂lder constant is locally bounded in $(x, t)$. Under assumptions on the supplementary regularity of the boundary $\partial \Omega \in C^{2+\alpha}$, and the H√∂lder continuity of $\langle u, v\rangle$ restricted to the parabolic boundary of $\Omega \times(0, T)$ (with suitable compatibility conditions on $\partial \Omega \times{0})$ we can obtain $C^{2+\alpha, 1+\alpha / 2}(\bar{\Omega} \times[0, T])$ regularity of solutions, which are in this case the classical ones, cf. e.g. [13, Chapter III, Section 12].
  • The general case is proved by exhausting the domain fi by an increasing sequence of smooth domains $\Omega_k$ for which (31) with the condition $\Phi_k = 0$ on $\partial\Omega$ is solved.
  • At the cost of some technical expense, on the basis of Theorem 2.1 and the ideas in [6], it is possible to extend the above result to less regular initial data: Upon an approximation argument, namely, one can assert global existence of small-data weak solutions with the asymptotic properties (2.2) and (2.3) for initial data with possibly discontinuous $u_0$ and $\nabla v_0$, satisfying only (2.1).
  • This result suggests a negative answer to Nanjundiah‚Äôs conjecture, which is the possibility of blow-up. Unfortunately, removing the smallness condition on $\tau > 0$ and the assumption of radial symmetry has been left as an open problem.

Uncertainty

  • it is not certain that

Reference

  • Some parts of the proofs in this paper will be merely sketched. In such a situation [9] is a standard reference, where the details of reasoning for the simplified problem may be found.

  • then the standard argument of covering guarantees

  • Purists will hate this, though many of them would not have noticed had I not pointed it out here.
  • When $\Lambda = \mathbb{R}^2$ and the additional invariance of the momentum of inertia is explicitly taken into account,
  • If a solution $(u, v)$ emanates from nonnegative initial data with suitably less regularity
  • The embedding $C^{0,\beta}(\Omega)\subset C^{0,\alpha}(\Omega)$, $0<\alpha<\beta\leq1$ is not dense. For example, $u\in C^1[0,1]$ and $\sqrt x\in C^{1/2}[0,1]$, but $|u-\sqrt x|_{C^{1/2}}=1$.
  • Models are derived by inserting into said structures a phenomenological description of interactions among pedestrians and between pedestrians and external actions.
  • As before, the square brackets denotes that functional dependence with respect to its arguments.
  • However, this simpler model might contradict empirical observations in some cases.
  • Some precise form of the speed $v$ can be given, for example in 190,187,188, such that the maximal speed is kept under low density conditions (free flow regime),i.e., up to a certain critical density $œÅ_c$, while the speed decreases to zero, with a polynomial type dependence on the local density, for values of $œÅ$ greater than $œÅ_c$ (slowdown zone).
  • Cellular differentiation follows, eventually resulting in a fruiting body structure composed of a ball of spore cells supported by a stalk of dead cells.
  • Quorum-sensing type behaviour occurs both prior to starvation and during aggregation stages.
  • During aggregation, cells secrete another molecule, counting factor (CF), which regulates the size of the aggregation to optimise the efficiency with which the fruiting body can disperse the cells, [5, 6]. The CF is thought to determine the group size via modulation of the adhesive and motility properties of the cells [52].
  • We incorporate the effect of such a mechanism by assuming the existence of a secondary chemical which allows the cells to determine the local density and alter the chemotactic response to the chemoattractant $v$ accordingly.
  • A key property of the above equations is their ability to give rise to spatial pattern formation when the chemical signal acts as an auto-attractant, that is, when cells both produce and migrate up gradients of the chemical signal.
  • The following lemma of which proof is done by elementary calculations is useful to estimate integrals of $u^2$ and $(\partial u/\partial r)^2$ with respect to $r$.

  • The following collection of comments should be considered as far from exhaustive with regard to aspects of language use.
  • The verbosity comes at a cost to human readability
  • Only with the increasing need in the day-to-day life of scientific programmers for simultaneous productivity and performance has the need for high performance dynamic languages become pressing.
  • We believe that the Julia programming language fulfills much of the Fortran dream: automatic translation of formulas into executable code. It allows programmers to write clear, high-level, generic and abstract code that closely resembles mathematical formulas, yet produces fast, low-level machine code that has traditionally only been generated by static languages.
  • double precision floating-point numbers
  • To be sure, experienced computer scientists tend to suspect that there is nothing new under the sun.
  • While it was nurtured at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, it is really the contributions from experts around the world that make it a joy to use for numerical computing.
  • It is also recognized as a general purpose computing language, unlike traditional numerical computing systems, allowing it to be used not only to prototype numerical algorithms, but also to deploy those algorithms and even serve results to the rest of the world.
  • succinctly, simply
  • Can we strike a balance between the human’s preference to avoid types and the computer’s need to know?

  • proceedings [plural] the official written report of a meeting, etc.

  • Most of the time when Rustaceans say ‚Äúcrate‚Äù, they mean library crate, and they use ‚Äúcrate‚Äù interchangeably with the general programming concept of a ‚Äúlibrary".

  • AUTHOR INFORMATION PACK of JOURNAL OF DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS Latex Instructions (elsevier.com)

    • Math formulae

      • Please submit math equations as editable text and not as images.
      • Present simple formulae in line with normal text where possible and use the solidus (/) instead of a horizontal line for small fractional terms, e.g., $X/Y$.
      • In principle, variables are to be presented in italics.
      • Powers of $e$ are often more conveniently denoted by $\exp$.
      • Number consecutively any equations that have to be displayed separately from the text (if referred to explicitly in the text).

    • Citation in text

      • Please ensure that every reference cited in the text is also present in the reference list (and vice versa).
      • Any references cited in the abstract must be given in full.
      • Unpublished results and personal communications are not recommended in the reference list, but may be mentioned in the text.
      • If these references are included in the reference list they should follow the standard reference style of the journal and should include a substitution of the publication date with either ‘Unpublished results’ or ‘Personal communication’.
      • Citation of a reference as ‘in press’ implies that the item has been accepted for publication.

    • Web references

      • As a minimum, the full URL should be given and the date when the reference was last accessed. Any further information, if known (DOI, author names, dates, reference to a source publication, etc.), should also be given. Web references can be listed separately (e.g., after the reference list) under a different heading if desired, or can be included in the reference list.

    • Data references

      • This journal encourages you to cite underlying or relevant datasets in your manuscript by citing them in your text and including a data reference in your Reference List. Data references should include the following elements: author name(s), dataset title, data repository, version (where available), year, and global persistent identifier. Add [dataset] immediately before the reference so we can properly identify it as a data reference. The [dataset] identifier will not appear in your published article.

    • Preprint references

      • Where a preprint has subsequently become available as a peer-reviewed publication, the formal publication should be used as the reference.
      • If there are preprints that are central to your work or that cover crucial developments in the topic, but are not yet formally published, these may be referenced.
      • Preprints should be clearly marked as such, for example by including the word preprint, or the name of the preprint server, as part of the reference. The preprint DOI should also be provided.

    • Reference management software

      • Most Elsevier journals have their reference template available in many of the most popular reference management software products. These include all products that support Citation Style Language styles, such as Mendeley. Using citation plug-ins from these products, authors only need to select the appropriate journal template when preparing their article, after which citations and bibliographies will be automatically formatted in the journal’s style. If no template is yet available for this journal, please follow the format of the sample references and citations as shown in this Guide.

    • Reference style

      • Text: Indicate references by number(s) in square brackets in line with the text. The actual authors can be referred to, but the reference number(s) must always be given. Example: ‘….. as demonstrated [3,6]. Barnaby and Jones [8] obtained a different result ….’
      • List: The list of references is arranged alphabetically and then numbered (numbers in square brackets).
  • It is assumed that the reader has a basic understanding of the domain name system as described by [2].
